youTubeVideos.title: Learning the new .NET Core 6 Minimal Web API and compare it with the Web API with Controllers
youTubeVideos.description:
I need a Web API so I dived into the tutorials for the 'full' Web API with Controllers and compared it to the new .NET Core Minimal web API. See how it was and how it is going...

After adding the menu (need some improvements but working for now) we are today looking at using the YouTube API to add a list of videos from one of the Playlists to the Blazor Web Project. This means building a Model, create some Mockup data and add this to the Index Page (the startup page). As this is a Blazor Web assembly website we need to build a Server API to actually collect the items from the playlist as we cannot store any access secrets in the Web assembly. That would be a security risk.

youTubeVideos.description:
Two weeks ago, we created the first Smallest Office Add-in Ever. The Pull Request is now updated to also show other Office hosts (Word, Excel, PowerPoint and more) so we are going to have another look at the OfficeDev PnP Repo to see where we can add to the PR.

We not only use the Repo but will also make use of the Certificate Technologies that we explored in our last two Live Coding sessions. So not only will you get an easy starting point for creating your Office Add-ins, but they will also run in a secure SSL/TLS context.

youTubeVideos.title: Signed Certificate for local Web Development
youTubeVideos.description:
Setting up a Self-Signed Certificate for your Web Development Project or Office Add-in is a bit tricky. Terminology is complex, a lot of options and no one demoes this on YouTube. Let's see if we can change this with today's Live Coding session.
 
Two weeks ago, we created the Smallest Office Add-in Ever, but we wanted to run it in a secure environment using self-signed certificates. Last week we looked at OpenSSL to create us self-signed certificates and see how this is performing in the context of our Smallest Office Add-in Ever.

Creating a small webserver that serves the Add-in to test on localhost is another thing. The PnP sample currently serves the pages from GitHub Pages. A cool feature to run your repo files directly from the GitHub site.

If you do want to run on your own machine you will need a small local running server, serving a secure (https!) website. For that you want a webserver with SSL certificates. That can be hard if you are just starting. I'll be looking for an easy solution to get around this issue in one of my following Live Coding sessions.

#OfficeDevelopment #GitHub #Add-in #PnP #OpenSSL #Certificate

youTubeVideos.title: Signed Certificate to your Localhost Website
youTubeVideos.description:
Last week we created the Smallest Office Add-in Ever, but we wanted to run it in a secure environment using self-signed certificates. Today in this Live Coding session we are going to look at OpenSSL to create us some self-signed certificates and see how this is performing in the context of our Smallest Office Add-in Ever.

Creating a small webserver that serves the Add-in to test on localhost is another thing. The PnP sample currently serves the pages from GitHub Pages. A cool feature to run your repo files directly from the GitHub site.

If you do want to run on your own machine you will need a small local running server, serving a secure (https!) website. For that you want a webserver with SSL certificates. That can be hard if you are just starting. I'll be looking for an easy solution to get around this issue in one of my following Live Coding sessions.

#OfficeDevelopment #GitHub #Add-in #PnP #OpenSSL #Certificate

youTubeVideos.title: in Ever
youTubeVideos.description:
In general, most Office Developer Samples are fairly complex. Today we are going to look at the smallest Add-in with only the basics that you need for creating your starter Add-in.

You only need a few lines of code, five or ten. That is all to get your first Add-in up and running. Besides that, your Office Host (Excel, Word etc.) needs to know where to look to see your Add-in. For that you need a manifest.xml. This contains all the pointers to where the website is and where it can find assets like buttons or Add-in Title and Description information.

Creating a small webserver that serves the Add-in to test on localhost is another thing. The PnP sample at this time serves the pages from Github Pages. A cool feature to run your repo files directly from the GitHub site.

If you do want to run on your own machine you will need a small local running server, serving a secure (https!) website. For that you want a webserver with SSL certificates. That can be hard if you are just starting. I'll be looking for an easy solution to get around this issue in one of my following Live Coding sessions.

#OfficeDevelopment #Github #Add-in #PnP

youTubeVideos.title: How to Layout with Blazor Code
youTubeVideos.description:
How to Layout with Blazor Code

Previous time in my Live Coding session I created my first base website that will host my Soft as in Software website, home of my multimedia challenge, combining Live Coding, YouTube, Blogging and Publishing. After adding my self-hosted WordPress Blog (https://blog.softasinsoftware.com) it is now time to do some research on layouts using Client Side Blazor.

Looking at the basics of Blazor Layout and already a bit of Blazor Routing to get the starter frame up and running. Many more items need to be researched, for instance Hot Reloading, YouTube APIs, CSS, and Bootstrap Styling and much, much more to go.

#Blazor #Layout

youTubeVideos.title: Host My Own WordPress Blog on Azure
youTubeVideos.description:
Last Live Coding Session I created my first base website that will host my Soft As In Software website, home of my multimedia challenge, combining Live Coding, YouTube, Blogging and Publishing. One part of the website needs to be my revamped WordPress Blog.

At this time, my Blog is hosted at a WordPress hosted location: https://www.maartenvanstam.nl that redirects to https://maartenvanstam.wordpress.com . Not ideal obviously, if only it was because all the crappy advertisements that appear on that site.

For that reason, I'm exploring to move my Blog to Azure. First to get rid of all the things mentioned above but also to learn from it. #EverydayLearning

#Self-Hosted #WordPress #Azure #WebApp

youTubeVideos.title: Create My First .NET 6 Blazor Website
youTubeVideos.description:
Rebranding my YouTube Channel made me think that I also will need a new website. The website should be like what I created at https://www.sdncast.nl with a YouTube page, with an overview of all my YouTube videos but also integrate a current blog and more.

Preferably all in Blazor to be able to do most web development in C# but I also think it should be able to integrate good old JavaScript/TypeScript pages. Using the upcoming .NET 6 version (still in preview at time of this session)

In this Live Coding session, I create a new Blazor Web Assembly (WASM) website, register my domain, and attach the SSL certificates.

For the current state you can go to www.softasinsoftware.com and see the progress so far.

youTubeVideos.title: Testing Outlook SSO PnP Sample Project
youTubeVideos.description:
To verify an issue (https://github.com/OfficeDev/PnP-OfficeAddins/issues/199)
with the Outlook SSO PnP sample, I evaluated this and initially failed big time. Same errors as in the GH Issue. Using VS 2022 at that time. Switched to VS 2019, rebuilt and that was working both on the client as in the web versions of Outlook. Now a few weeks later it failed again. In this Live Coding session, you'll see that it still is highly unstable and confirming the issue is valid.

Update: A fix was added just after the Live Coding session:
https://github.com/OfficeDev/PnP-OfficeAddins/pull/205
Tested that off camera, found another remaining issue and I fixed this as well:
https://github.com/OfficeDev/PnP-OfficeAddins/pull/206

Both these fixes solved the issues I showed here in this Live Coding sessions.
Will do a recap in another video to show that it is working now.
